subject: Data
title: Truncated Y-Axes: The Simplest Deception
description: A short lesson to help you apply Truncated Y-Axes: The Simplest Deception.

hook.text: A politician's approval rating dropped from 52% to 48%. The news chart made it look like a cliff dive.

buildup.text: The trick: start the Y-axis at 46% instead of 0%. A 4-point change fills the entire chart height.

discovery.text: Truncated Y-axes are the most common chart deception â€” and the hardest to spot for casual viewers.

twist.text: Sometimes truncation is legitimate â€” a 0.1Â° rise in global temperature matters. Context is everything.

climax.text: The rule of thumb: always check where the axis starts before believing what a chart 'shows.'

punchline.text: A dishonest axis can turn a ripple into a tsunami.

quiz.question: What does a truncated Y-axis do to a chart?
options: Exaggerates small changes to look dramatic
